sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: You'll be prepar'd upon that head.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I shall be prepar'd, never fear; away with you.

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: But hold, I had forgot: not a word of the diamonds; leave that matter to my management.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Hell and vexation! Get out of the room, or I shall run distracted. Exit Mrs. Fulmer. Of a certain, Belcour, thou art born to be the fool of woman: sure no man sins with so much repentance, or repents with so little amend
ment, as I do. I cannot give away another person's pro
perty, honour forbids me; and I positively cannot give up the girl; love, passion, constitution, every thing protests against that. How shall I decide? I cannot bring myself to break a trust, and I am not at present in the humour to baulk my inclinations. Is there no middle way? Let me consider—There is, there is: my good genius has pre
sented me with one; apt, obvious, honourable; the girl shall not go without her baubles, I'll not go without the girl, Miss Rusport shan't lose her diamonds, I'll save Dudley from destruction, and every party shall be a gainer by the project.

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: Miss Dudley, this is the worthy gentleman you wish to see; this is Mr. Belcour.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: As I live, the very man that beset me in the streets.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
An angel, by this light! Oh I am gone past all re
trieving!

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Mrs. Fulmer, Sir, informs me you are the gentleman from whom my father has received such civilities.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Oh! never name 'em.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Pardon me, Mr. Belcour, they must be both named and remember'd; and if my father was here—

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I am much better pleased with his representative.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: That title is my brother's, Sir; I have no claim to it.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I believe it.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: But as neither he nor my father were fortunate enough to be at home, I cou'd not resist the opportunity—

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Nor I neither, by my soul, Madam: let us improve it, therefore. I am in love with you to distraction; I was charmed at the first glance; I attempted to accost you; you fled; I follow'd; but was defeated of an interview; at length I have obtain'd one, and seize the opportunity of casting my person and my fortune at your feet.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: You astonish me! Are you in your senses, or do you make a jest of my misfortunes? Do you ground pretences on your generosity, or do you make a practice of this folly with every woman you meet?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Upon my life, no: As you are the handsomest woman I ever met, so you are the first to whom I ever made the like professions: as for my generosity, Madam, I must re
fer you on that score to this good lady, who I believe has something to offer in my behalf.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
Don't build upon that, Sir; I must have better proofs of your generosity, than the mere divestment of a little superfluous dross, before I can credit the sincerity of pro
fessions so abruptly deliver'd.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Oh! ye Gods and Goddesses, how her anger animates her beauty!

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: Stay, Sir; if you stir a step after her, I renounce your interest for ever; why you'll ruin every thing.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Well, I must have her, cost what it will: I see she understands her own value tho'; a little superfluous dross, truly! She must have better proofs of my generosity.

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: 'Tis exactly as I told you; your money she calls dross; she's too proud to stain her fingers with your coin; bait your illegible ok well with jewels; try that experiment, and she's your own.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Take 'em; let 'em go; lay 'em at her feet; I must get out of the scrape as I can; my propensity is irresistible: there! you have 'em; they are yours; they are her's; but remember they are a trust; I commit them to her keeping till I can buy 'em off with something she shall think more valuable; now tell me when shall I meet her?

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: How can I tell that? Don't you see what an alarm you have put her into? Oh! you are a rare one! But go your ways for this while; leave her to my management, and come to me at seven this evening; but remember not to bring empty pockets with you—Ha! ha! ha!

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: MISS RUSPORT enters, followed by a servant.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Desire Mr. Stockwell to walk in.

sp.speaker: STOCWELL.
sp.p: Madam, your most obedient servant: I am honoured with your commands, by Captain Dudley; and have brought the money with me as you directed: I understand the sum you have occasion for is two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: It is, Sir; I am quite confounded at your taking this trouble upon yourself, Mr. Stockwell.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
There is a Bank-note, Madam, to the amount: your jewels are in safe hands, and will be delivered to you di
rectly.
If I had been happy in being better known to you, I should have hoped you would not have thought it necessary to place a deposit in my hands for so trifling a sum as you have now required me to supply you with.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: The bawbles I sent you may very well be spared; and, as they are the only security, in my present situation, I can give you, I could wish you would retain them in your hands: when I am of age, (which, if I live a few months, I shall be) I will replace your favour, with thanks.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
It is obvious, Miss Rusport, that your charms will suffer no impeachment by the absence of these superficial orna
ments; but they should be seen in the suite of a woman of fashion, not as creditors to whom you are indebted for your appearance, but as subservient attendants, which help to make up your equipage.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
Mr. Stockwell is determined not to wrong the con
fidence I reposed in his politeness.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I have only to request, Madam, that you will allow Mr. Belcour, a young gentleman, in whose happiness I parti
cularly interest myself, to have the honour of delivering you the box of jewels.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Most gladly; any friend of yours cannot fail of being welcome here.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I flatter myself you will not find him totally undeserving your good opinion; an education, not of the strictest kind, and strong animal spirits, are apt sometimes to betray him into youthful irregularities; but an high principle of ho
nour, and an uncommon benevolence, in the eye of candor, will, I hope, atone for any faults, by which these good qualities are not impaired.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: I dare say Mr. Belcour's behaviour wants no apology: we've no right to be over strict in canvassing the morals of a common acquaintance.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I wish it may be my happiness to see Mr. Belcour in the
list, not of your common, but particular acquaintance, of your friends, Miss Rusport—I dare not be more explicit.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
Nor need you, Mr. Stockwell: I shall be studious to deserve his friendship; and, though I have long since un
alterably placed my affections on another, I trust, I have not left myself insensible to the merits of Mr. Belcour; and hope that neither you nor he will, for that reason, think me less worthy your good opinion and regards.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Miss Rusport, I sincerely wish you happy: I have no doubt you have placed your affection on a deserving man; and I have no right to combat your choice.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: How honourable is that behaviour! Now, if Charles was here, I should be happy. The old lady is so fond of her new Irish acquaintance, that I have the whole house at my disposal.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: BELCOUR enters, preceded by a Servant.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I illegible your honour's pardon; I thought my young lady was illegible ere: who shall I inform her wou'd speak to her?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Belcour is my name, Sir; and pray beg your lady to put herself in illegible hurry on my account; for I'd sooner see the devil than see her face Exit Servant. In the name of all that's mischievous, why did Stockwell drive me hither in soon haste? A pretty figure, truly, I shall make: an am
bassador without credentials. Blockhead that I was to charge myself with her diamonds; officious, meddling puppy! Now they are irretrievably gone: that suspicious jade Fulmer woudn't part even with a fight of them, tho' I would have ransom'd 'em at twice their value. Now must I trust to my poor wits to bring me off: a lamentable de
pendance. Fortune be my helper! Here comes the girl— If she is noble minded, as she is said to be, she will forgive me; if not, 'tis a lost cause; for I have not thought of one word in my excuse.

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Mr. Belcour, I'm proud to see you: your friend, Mr. Stockwell, prepared me to expect this honour; and I am happy in the opportunity of being known to you.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: A fine girl, by my soul! Now what a cursed hang-dog do I look like!

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: You are newly arrived in this country, Sir?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Just landed, Madam; just set a-shore, with a large cargo of Muscovado sugars, rum-puncheons, mahogany-slabs, wet sweet-meats, and green paroquets.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: May I ask you how you like London, Sir?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: To admiration: I think the town and the town's-folk are exactly suited; 'tis a great, rich, overgrown, noisy, tumultuous place: the whole morning is a bustle to get money, and the whole afternoon is a hurry to spend it.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Are these all the observations you have made?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
No, Madam; I have observed the women are very cap
tivating, and the men very soon caught.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Ay, indeed! Whence do you draw that conclusion?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: From infallible guides; the first remark I collect from what I now see, the second from what I now feel.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Oh, the deuce take you! but to wave this subject; I believe, Sir, this was a visit of business, not compliment; was it not?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Ay; now comes on my execution.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: You have some foolish trinkets of mine, Mr. Belcour; havn't you?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: No, in truth; they are gone in search of a trinket, still more foolish than themselves.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Some diamonds I mean, Sir; Mr. Stockwell inform'd me you was charged with 'em.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Oh, yes, Madam; but I have the most treacherous me
mory in life—Here they are! Pray put them up; they're all right; you need not examine 'em

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Hey-dey! right, Sir! Why these are not my diamonds; these are quite different; and, as it should seem, of much greater value.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Upon my life I'm glad on't; for then I hope you value 'em more than your own.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
As a purchaser I should, but not as an owner; you mi
stake, these belong to somebody else.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: 'Tis yours, I'm afraid, that belong to somebody else.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: What is it yon mean? I must insist upon your taking 'em back again.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Pray, madam, don't do that; I shall infallibly lose them; I have the worst luck with diamonds of any man living.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: That you might well say, was you to give me these in the place of mine; but pray, Sir, what is the reason of all this? Why have you changed the jewels? and where have you disposed of mine?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Miss Rusport, I cannot invent a lie for my life; and, if it was to save it, I coudn't tell one: I am an idle, dis
sipated, unthinking fellow, not worth your notice: in short, I am a West-Indian; and you must try me accord
ing
to the charter of my colony, not by a jury of En
glish spinsters: truth is, I've given away your jewels; caught with a pair of sparkling eyes, whose lustre blinded their's, I served your property, as I shou'd my own, and lavish'd it away; let me not totally despair of your for
giveness: I frequently do wrong, but never with impu
nity; if your displeasure is added to my own, my punish
ment will be too severe. When I parted from the jewels, I had not the honour of knowing their owner.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
Mr. Belcour, your sincerity charms me, I enter at once into your character, and I make all the allowances for it you can desire. I take your jewels for the present, be
cause I know there is no other way of reconciling you to yourself; but If I give way to your spirit in one point, you must yield to mine in another; remember I will not keep more than the value of my own jewels: there is no need to be pillaged by more than one woman at a time, Sir.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Now may every blessing that can crown your virtues, and reward your beauty, be shower'd upon you; may you meet admiration without envy, love without jealousy: and old age without malady! may the man of your heart be ever constant, and you never meet a less penitent, or less grateful offender than myself.

div.stage: Servant enters and delivers a letter.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Does your letter require such haste?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I was bade to give it into your own hands, madam.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
From Charles Dudley, I see—have I your permission? Good Heaven, what do I read! Mr. Belcour you are concern'd in this—
Dear Charlotte;
in the midst of our distress, Providence has cast a benefactor in our way, after the most unexpected manner: a young West Indian, rich, and with a warmth of heart peculiar to his climate, has rescued my father from his troubles, satisfied his wants, and enabled him to accomplish his exchange: when I relate to you the manner in which
this was done, you will be charm'd; I can only now add, that it was by chance we found out that his name is Belcour, and that he is a friend of Mr. Stock
well's. I lose not a moment's time in making you ac
quainted with this fortunate event for reasons which delicacy obliges me to suppress; but, perhaps, if you have not received the money on your jewels, you will not think it necessary now to do it. I have the honour to be,
Dear Madam, most faithfully yours, CHARLES DUDLEY.
Is this your doing, Sir? Never was generosity so worthily exerted.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Or so greatly overpaid.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
After what you have now done for this noble, but in
digent, family, let me not scruple to unfold the whole situation of my heart to you. Know then, Sir, (and don't think the worse of me for the frankness of my declaration) that such is my attachment to the son of that worthy officer whom you relieved, that the moment I am of age, and in possession of my fortune, I shou'd hold myself the happiest of women to share it with young Dudley.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Say you so, madam! then let me perish if I don't love and reverence you above all woman kind; and if such is your generous resolution, never wait till you're of age; life is too short, pleasure too fugitive; the soul grows narrower every hour; I'll equip you for your escape; I'll convoy you to the man of your heart, and away with you then to the first hospitable parson, that will take you in.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
O blessed be the torrid zone for ever, whose rapid ve
getation quickens nature into such benignity! These lati
tudes are made for politics and philosophy; friendship has no root in this soil. But had I spirit to accept your offer, which is not improbable, wou'dn't it be a mortifying thing, for a fond girl to find herself mistaken, and sent back to her home, like a vagrant; and such, for what I know, might be my case.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Then he ought to be proscribed the society of mankind for ever——Ay, ay, 'tis the sham sister makes him thus indifferent; 'twill be a meritorious office to take that girl out of the way.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Miss Dudley to wait on you, madam.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Miss Dudley.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mr. Belcour? are you frighted at the name of a pretty girl? 'tis the sister of him we were speaking of—pray admit her.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: The sister! So, so; he has imposed upon her too— this is an extraordinary visit truly. Upon my soul the assurance of some folks is not to be accounted for.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: I insist upon your not running away; you'll be charm'd with Louisa Dudley.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I am charm'd with her.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: You've seen her then; have you?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I've seen her.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Well, isn't she a delightful girl?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Very delightful.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Why, you answer as if you was in a court of justice; O'my conscience! I believe you are caught; I've a notion she has trick'd you out of your heart.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I believe she has, and you out of your jewels; for to tell you the truth, she's the very person I gave 'em to.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: You gave her my jewels! Louisa Dudley my jewels? admirable; inimitable! oh, the fly little jade! but hush, here she comes; I don't know how I shall keep my countenance.
My dear, I'm rejoiced to see you; how d'ye do? I beg leave to introduce Mr. Belcour, a very worthy friend of mine; I believe, Louisa, you have seen him before.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: I have met the gentleman.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: You have met the gentleman; well, Sir, and you have met the lady; in short, you have met each other; why then don't you speak to each other? How you both stand tongue-tied, and fix'd as statues——Ha, ha, ha! Why you'll fall a-sleep by-and-by.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Fye upon you; fye upon you; is this fair?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Upon my soul I never look'd so like a fool in my life; the assurance of that girl puts me quite down aside..

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Sir—Mr. Belcour—Was it your pleasure to advance any thing? Not a syllable. Come, Louisa, womens wit, they say, is never at a loss—Nor you neither? Speechless both—Why you was merry enough before this lady came in.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
I am sorry I have been any interruption to your happi
ness, Sir.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Madam! Is that all you can say? but come, my dear girl, I won't teaze you: apropos! I must shew you what a fine present this dumb gentleman has made me; are not illegible ese handsome diamonds?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, they seem very fine; but I am no judge of these things.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Oh, you wicked little hypocrite, you are no judge of these things, Louisa; you have no diamonds, not you.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: You know I havn't, Miss Rusport: you know those things are infinitely above my reach.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: She does tell a lie with an admirable countenance, that's true enough.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
What ails you, Charlotte? What impertinence have I been guilty of that you should find it necessary to humble me at such a rate? if you are happy, long may you be so; but, surely, it can be no addition to it to make me mi
serable.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: So serious! there must be some mystery in this—Mr. Belcour will you leave us together? You see I treat you with all the familiarity of an old acquaintance already.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Oh, by all means; pray command me. Miss Rusport, I'm your most obedient! By your condescension in accept
ing those poor trifles, I am under eternal obligations to you—To you, Miss Dudley, I shall not offer a word on that subject: you despise finery; you have a soul above it; I adore your spirit; I was rather unprepared for meeting you here; but I shall hope for an opportunity of making myself better known to you.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Louisa Dudley, you surprize me; I never saw you act thus before: can't you bear a little innocent raillery before the man of your heart?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
The man of my heart, Madam? Be assured I never was so visionary to aspire to any man whom Miss Rusport ho
nours with her choice.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
My choice, my dear! Why we are playing at cross pur
poses: how enter'd it into your head that Mr. Belcour was the man of my choice?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Why didn't he present you with those diamonds?

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Well; perhaps he did—and pray, Louisa, have you no diamonds?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: I diamonds truly! Who should give me diamonds?

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Who, but this very gentleman: Apropos! here comes your brother—

I insist upon referring our dispute to him: your sister and I, Charles, have a quarrel; Belcour, the hero of your letter, has just left us—some how or other, Louisa's bright eyes have caught him; and the poor fellow's fallen despe
rately in love with her—(don't interrupt me, hussey)— Well, that's excusable enough, you'll say; but the jet of the story is, that this hair-brain'd spark, who does nothing like other people, has given her the very identical jewels, which you pledged for me to Mr. Stockwell; and will you believe that this little demure slut made up a face, and squeezed out three or four hypocritical tears, because I ral
lied her about it?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: I'm all astonishment! Louisa, tell me without reserve, has Mr. Belcour given you any diamonds?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: None, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Has he made any professions to you?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: He has, but altogether in a stile so whimsical and capricious, that the best which can be said of them is to tell you that they seem'd more the result of good spirits than good manners.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Ay, ay, now the murder's out; he's in love with her, and she has no very great dislike to him; trust to my observation, Charles, for that: as to the diamonds, there's some mistake about them, and you must clear it up: three minutes conversation with him will put every thing in a right train; go, go, Charles, 'tis a brother's business; about it instantly; ten to one you'll find him over the way at Mr. Stockwell's.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: I confess I'm impatient to have the case clear'd up; I'll take your advice, and find him out: good bye to you.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Your servant; my life upon it you'll find Belcour a man of honour. Come, Louisa, let us adjourn to my dressing-room; I've a little private business to transact with you, before the old lady comes up to tea, and interrupts us.

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p: Patty, wasn't Mr. Belcour with you?

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: He was, and is now shut up in my chamber, in high expectation of an interview with Miss Dudley; she's at present with her brother, and 'twas with some difficulty I persuaded my hot-headed spark to wait 'till he has left her.

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p: Well, child, and what then?

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: Why then, Mr. Fulmer, I think it will be time for you and me to steal a march, and be gone.

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p: So this is all the fruit of your ingenious project; a shameful overthrow, or a sudden flight.

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: Why, my project was a mere impromptu, and can at worst but quicken our departure a few days; you know we had fairly outliv'd our credit here, and a trip to Boulogne is no ways unseasonable. Nay, never droop, man—Hark! hark! here's enough to bear charges.

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p: Let me see, let me see: this weighs well; this is of the right sort: why your West-Indian bled freely.

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p:
But that's not all: look here! Here are the sparklers! shewing the jewels Now what d'ye think of my per
formances? Heh! a foolish scheme, isn't it? — a silly woman—?

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p:
Thou art a Judith, a Joan of Arc, and I'll march under thy banners, girl, to the world's end: Come, let's be
gone; I've little to regret; my creditors may share the old books amongst them, they'll have occasion for philosophy to support their loss; they'll find enough upon my shelves: The world is my library; I read mankind—Now, Patty, lead the way.

sp.speaker: MRS. FULMER.
sp.p: Adieu, Belcour!

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Well, Louisa, I confess the force of what you say: I accept Miss Rusport's bounty, and when you see my generous Charlotte, tell her—but have a care, there is a selfishness even in gratitude, when it is too profuse; to be over thankful for any one favour, is in effect to lay out for another; the best return I cou'd make my benefactress wou'd be never to see her more.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: I understand you.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
We, that are poor, Louisa, shou'd be cautious; for this reason I wou'd guard you against Belcour; at least till I can unravel the mystery of Miss Rusport's diamonds; I was disappointed of finding him at Mr. Stockwell's, and am now going in search of him again: he may intend honourably, but I confess to you I am stagger'd; think no more of him, therefore, for the present: of this be sure, while I have life, and you have honour, I will pro
tect you, or perish in your defence.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
Think of him no more! Well, I'll obey; but if a wand'ring uninvited thought should creep by chance into my bosom, must I not give the harmless wretch a shelter? Oh! yes; the great artificer of the human heart knows every thread he wove into its fabric, nor puts his work to harder uses than it was made to bear: my wishes then,
my guiltless ones I mean, are free; How fast they spring within me at that sentence! Down, down, ye busy crea
tures! Whither wou'd you carry me? Ah! there is one amongst you, a forward, new intruder, that in the like
ness of an offending, generous man, grows into favour with my heart. Fye, fye upon it! Belcour pursues, insults me; yet such is the fatality of my condition, that what shou'd rouse resentment, only calls up love.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Alone, by all that's happy!

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Oh! shriek not, start not, stir not, loveliest creature! but let me kneel, and gaze upon your beauties.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Belcour, rise! What is it you do?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
See, I obey you; mould me as you will, behold your ready servant! New to your country, ignorant of your manners, habits, and desires, I put myself into your hands for instruction; make me only such as you can like your
self, and I shall be happy.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
I must not hear this, Mr. Belcour; go; should he, that parted from me but this minute, now return, I trem
ble for the consequence.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Fear nothing; let him come: I love you, Madam; he'll find it hard to make me unsay that.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: You terrify me; your impetuous temper frightens me; you know my situation; it is not generous to pursue me thus.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: True; I do know your situation, your real one, Miss Dudley, and am resolv'd to snatch you from it; 'twill be a meritorious act; the old Captain shall rejoice; Miss Rusport shall be made happy; and even he, even your beloved brother, with whose resentment you threaten me, shall in the end applaud and thank me: Come, thou'rt a dear enchanting girl, and I'm determin'd not to live a minute longer without thee.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Hold, are you mad? I see you are a bold, assuming man, and know not where to stop.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Who that beholds such beauty can? By Heaven, you put my blood into a flame. Provoking girl! is it within the stretch of my fortune to content you? What is it you can further ask that I am not ready to grant?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Yes, with the same facility that you bestow'd upon me Miss Rusport's diamonds. For shame! for shame! was that a manly story?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: So! so! these devilish diamonds meet me every where— Let me perish if I meant you any harm: Oh! I cou'd tear my tongue out for saying a word about the matter.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Go to her then, and contradict it; till that is done, my reputation is at stake.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Her reputation! Now she has got upon that, she'll go on for ever.—What is there I will not do for your sake? I will go to Miss Rusport.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Do so; restore her own jewels to her, which I suppose you kept back for the purpose of presenting others to her of a greater value; but for the future, Mr. Belcour, when you wou'd do a galant action to that lady, don't let it be at my expence.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I see where she points: she is willing enough to give up Miss Rusport's diamonds, now she finds she shall be a gainer by the exchange. Be it so! 'tis what I wish'd.— Well, Madam, I will return Miss Rusport her own jewels, and you shall have others of tenfold their value.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: No, Sir, you err most widely; it is my good opinion, not my vanity, which you must bribe.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Why, what the devil wou'd she have now?—Miss Dudley, it is my wish to obey and please you, but I have some apprehension that we mistake each other.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: I think we do: tell me, then, in few words, what it is you aim at.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: In few words, then, and in plain honesty, I must tell you, so entirely am I captivated with you, that had you but been such as it wou'd have become me to have call'd my wife, I had been happy in knowing you by that name; as it is, you are welcome to partake my fortune, give me in return your person, give me pleasure, give me love; free, disencumber'd, antimatrimonial love.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Stand off, and let me never see you more.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Hold, hold, thou dear, tormenting, tantalizing girl! Upon my knees I swear you shall not stir till you've con
sented to my bliss.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Unhand me, Sir: O Charles! protect me, rescue me, redress me.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: How's this? Rise, villain, and defend yourself.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: The man who wrongs that lady is a villain—Draw!

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Never fear me, young gentleman; brand me for a coward, if I baulk you.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Yet hold! Let me not be too hasty: your name, I think, is Belcour?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
How is it, Mr. Belcour, you have done this mean, un
manly wrong; beneath the mask of gener illegible ity to g illegible ve this fatal stab to our domestic peace? Your might have had my thanks, my blessing: take my defiance illegible Dudley speaks to you, the brother, the pr illegible tect illegible of that i illegible jur'd lady.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: The brother? Give yourself a illegible title.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: What is't you mean?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Come, come, I know both her and you: I found you, Sir, (but how or why I know not) in the good graces of Miss Rusport—(yes, colour at the named) I gave you no disturbance there, never broke illegible upon you illegible n that illegible ch and plenteous quarter; but, when I cou'd have blasted all your projects with a word, spar'd you, in foolish pity spar'd you, nor rouz'd her from the fond credulity in which your artifice had lull'd her.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
No, Sir, nor boasted to her of the splendid present you had made my poor Louisa; the illegible , Mr. Bel illegible our. How was that? What can you plead to that arraign

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Hold, hold, for Heaven's fake hold! Charles! Mr. Belcour! Help! Sir, Sir, make haste, they'll murder one another.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Hell and confusion! What's all this uproar for? Can't you leave off cutting one another's throats, and mind what the poor girl says to you? You've done a notable thing, hav'n't you, both, to put her into such a flurry? I think, o' my conscience, she's the most frighted of the three.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Dear Louisa, recollect yourself; why did you interfere? 'Tis in your cause.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Now cou'd I kill him for caressing her.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: O Sir, your most obedient! You are the gentleman I had the honour of meeting here before; you was then running off at full speed like a Calmuck, now you are tilting and driving like a Bedlamite with this lad here, that seems as mad as yourself: 'Tis pity but your country had a little more employment for you both.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Mr. Dudley, when you've recover'd the lady, you know where I am to be found.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Well then, can't you stay where you are, and that will save the trouble of looking after you? Yon volatile fellow thinks to give a man the meeting by getting out of his way: by my soul 'tis a round-about method that of his. But I think he call'd you Dudley: Hark'e, young man, are you son of my friend the old Captain?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: I am. Help me to convey this lady to her chamber, and I shall be more at leisure to answer your questions.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
Ay will I: come along, pretty one; if you're had wrong done you, young man, you need look no further for a se
cond, Dennis O'Flaherty's your man for that; but never draw your sword before a woman, Dudley; damn it, never while you live draw your sword before a woman.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: An elderly gentleman, who says his name is Varland, desires leave to wait on your ladyship.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Shew him in; the very man I wish to see: Varland; he was Sir Oliver's sollicitor, and privy to all his affairs; he brings some good tidings; some fresh mortgage, or ano
ther bond come to light; they start up every day. VAR
LAND enters. Mr. Varland, I'm glad to see you; you're heartily welcome, honest Mr. Varland; you and I havn't met since our late irreparable loss: how have you passed your time this age?

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Truly, my lady, ill enough: I thought I must have followed good Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Alack-a-day, poor man! Well, Mr. Varland, you find me here overwhelmed with trouble and fatigue; torn to pieces with a multiplicity of affairs; a great fortune poured upon me unsought for and unexpected: 'twas my good fa
ther's will and pleasure it should be so, and I must submit.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Your ladyship inherits under a will made in the year forty-five, immediately after Captain Dudley's marriage with your sister.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p: I do so, Mr. Varland; I do so.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: I well remember it; I engrossed every syllable; but I am surprized to find your ladyship see so little store by this vast accession.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Why you know, Mr. Varland, I am a moderate wo
man;

                      had enough before; a small matter satisfies me; and Sir Stephen Rusport (Heaven be his portion!) took care I shoudn't want that.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p:
Very true; very true, he did so; and I am overjoyed at finding your ladyship in this disposition; for, truth to say, I was n illegible t without apprehension the news I have to com
municate would have been of some prejudice to your lady
ship's tranquility.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p: News, Sir! What news have you for me?

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Nay, nothing to alarm you; a trifle, in your present way of thinking: I have a will of Sir Oliver's you have never seen.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p: A will! Impossible! How came you by it, pray?

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: I drew it up, at his command, in his last illness: it will save you a world of trouble: it gives his whole estate from you to his grandson, Charles Dudley.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p: To Dudley? His estate to Charles Dudley? I can't support it! I shall faint! You've killed me, you vile man! I never shall survive it!

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Lock'e there now: I protest, I thought you would have rejoiced at being clear of the incumbrance.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p: 'Tis false; 'tis all a forgery, concerted between you and Dudley; why else did I never hear of it before?

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p:
Have patience, my lady, and I'll tell you: By Sir Oli
ver's direction, I was to deliver this will into no hands but his grandson Dudley's: the young gentleman happen'd to

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: So, so! My lady and her lawyer have retired to close confabulation: now, M illegible ster, if you are the generous man I take you for, grant me o illegible e favour.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: A word to the wise! I'm an old campaigner; make the best use of your time; and trust me for tying the old cat up to the picket.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Hush! hush! not so loud.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
'Tis the office of a centinel, Major, you have under
taken, rather than that of a field-officer.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
'Tis the office of a friend, my dear boy; and, there
fore, no disgrace to a general.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: Well, Charles, will you commit yourself to me for a few minutes?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Most readily; and let me, before one goes by, tender you the only payment I can ever make for your abundant generosity.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
Hold, hold! so vile a thing as money must not come be
tween us. What shall I say! O Charles! O Dudley! What difficulties have you thrown upon me! Familiarly as we have lived, I shrink at what I'm doing; and, anxiously as I have sought this opportunity, my fears almost persuade me to abandon it.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: You alarm me!

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
Your looks and actions have been so distant, and at this moment are so deterring, that, was it not for the hope that delicacy, and not disgust, inspires this conduct in you, I should sink with shame and apprehension; but time presses; and I must speak; and plainly too—Was you now in pos
session
of your grandfather's estate, as justly you ought to be, and was you inclined to seek a companion for life, should you, or should you not, in that case, honour at your unworthy Charlotte with your choice?

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: D'ye pause? Put me into his hands, while you prov illegible the means for our escape: he is the most generous, the most honourable of men.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
Run, run, for holy St. Antony's sake, to horse and away! The conscience is broke up, and the old lady ad
vances
upon a full piedmontese trot, within pistol-shot of your encampment.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p:
Here, here, down the back-stairs! O, Charles, remem
ber me!

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Farewell! Now, now I feel myself a coward.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Ask no questions, but be gone: she has cooled the lad's courage, and wonders he feels like a coward. There's a damn'd deal of mischief brewing between this hyena and her lawyer: egad I'll step behind this screen and listen▪ a good soldier must sometimes fight in ambush as well as open field

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Sure I heard somebody. Hark! No; only the servants going down the back stairs. Well, Mr. Varland, I think then we are agreed; you'll take my money; and your con
science no longer stands in your way.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p:
Your father was my benefactor; his will ought to be sa
cred; but, if I commit it to the flames, how will he be the wiser? Dudley, 'tis true, has done me no harm; but five thousand pounds will do me much good; so, in short, Madam, I take your offer; I will confer with my clerk, who witnessed the will; and to-morrow morning put it into your hands, upon condition you put five thousand good pounds into mine.

sp.speaker: LADY RUSPORT.
sp.p: 'Tis a bargain; I'll be ready for you: farewell.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p:
Let me consider—Five thousand pounds prompt pay
ment for destroying this scrap of paper, not worth five far
things; 'tis a fortune easily earn'd; yes, and 'tis another man's fortune easily thrown away: 'tis a good round sum
to be paid down at once for a bribe, but 'tis a damn'd rogue's trick in me to take it.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: So, so! this fellow speaks truth to himself, tho' he lies to other people—but hush!

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: 'Tis breaking the trust of my benefactor; that's a foul crime, but he's dead, and can never reproach me with it: and 'tis robbing young Dudley of his lawful patrimony, that's a hard case, but he's alive and knows nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: These lawyers are so used to bring off the rogueries of others, that they are never without an excuse for their own.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Were I assured now that Dudley would give me half the money for producing this will, that Lady Rusport does for concealing it, I wou'd deal with him, and be an honest man at half price; I wish every gentleman of my profession cou'd lay his hand on his heart and say the same thing.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: A bargain, old gentleman! Nay, never start, nor stare, you wasn't afraid of your own conscience, never be afraid of me.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Of you, Sir; who are you, pray?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: I'll tell you who I am: you seem to wish to be honest, but want the heart to set about it; now I am the very man in the world to make you so; for if you do not give me up that paper this very instant, by the soul of me, fellow, I will not leave one whole bone in your skin that shan't be broken.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: What right have you, pray, to take this paper from me?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
What right have you, pray, to keep it from young Dudley? I don't know what it contains, but I am apt to think it will be safer in my hands than in your's; there
fore give it me without more words, and save yourself a beating: do now; you had best.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I may as well make a grace of necessity. There! I have acquitted my conscience, at the expence of five thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Five thousand pounds! Mercy upon me! When there are such temptations in the law, can we wonder if some of the corps are a disgrace to it?

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: Well, you have got the paper; if you are an honest man, give it to Charles Dudley.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: An honest man! look at me friend, I am a soldier, this is not the livery of a knave; I am an Irishman, honey, mine is not the country of dishonor. Now, Sirrah, be gone; if you enter these doors, or give Lady Rusport the least item of what has passed, I will cut off both your ears, and rob the pillory of its due.

sp.speaker: VARLAND.
sp.p: I wish I was once fairly out of his sight.

div.head: SCENE X.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I must disclose myself to Belcour; this noble instance of his generosity, which old Dudley has been relating, allies me to him at once; concealment becomes too pain
ful; I shall be proud to own him for my son—But see, he's here.

div.stage: BELCOUR enters and throws himself on a sopha.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: O my curst tropical constitution! wou'd to Heaven I had been dropt upon the snows of Lapland, and never felt the blessed influence of the Sun, so I had never burnt with these inflammatory passions!

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: So, so, you seem disorder'd, Mr. Belcour.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Disorder'd, Sir! why did I ever quit the soil in which I grew; what evil planet drew me from that warm sunny region, where naked nature walks without disguise, into this cold contriving artificial country?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you've met a rascal; what o'that? general conclusions are illiberal.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: No, Sir, I've met reflection by the way; I've come from folly, noise and fury, and met a silent monitor—Well, well, a villian! 'twas not to be pardon'd—pray never mind me, Sir.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Alas! my heart bleeds for him.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
And yet I might have heard him: now plague upon that blundering Irishman for coming in as he did; the hurry of the deed might paliate the event: deliberate ex
ecution has less to plead—Mr. Stockwell, I am bad com
pany to you.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Oh, Sir; make no excuse. I think you have not found me forward to pry into the secrets of your pleasures and pursuits; 'tis not my disposition; but there are times, when want of curiosity, wou'd be want of friendship.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, mine is a case wherein you and I shall never think alike; the punctilious rules, by which I am bound, are not to be found in your ledgers, nor will pass current in the compting-house of a trader.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Sir; if you think I can render you any service; it may be worth your trial to confide in me; if not, your secret is safer in your own bosom.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: That sentiment demands my confidence: pray, sit down by me. You must know, I have an affair of honour on my hands with young Dudley; and tho' I put up with no man's insult, yet I wish to take away no man's life.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I know the young man, and am appris'd of your gene
rosity to his father, what can have bred a quarrel between you?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
A foolish passion on my side, and a haughty provocation on his. There is a girl, Mr. Stockwell, whom I have un
fortunately seen, of most uncommon beauty; she has withal an air of so much natural modesty, that had I not had good assurance of her being an attainable wanton, I declare I shou'd as soon have thought of attempting the chastity of Diana.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Hey-day, do you interrupt us?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, there's an Irish gentleman will take no denial; he says he must see Mr. Belcour directly, upon business of the last consequence.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Admit him; 'tis the Irish officer that parted us, and brings me young Dudley's challenge; I should have made a long story of it, and he'll tell it you in three words.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Save you, my dear; and you, Sir! I have a little bit of a word in private for you.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Pray deliver your commands; this gentleman is my in
timate friend.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
Why then, Ensign Dudley will be glad to measure swords with you, yonder at the London Tavern, in Bi
shopsgate-Street, at nine o'clock—you know the place.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I do; and shall observe the appointment.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Will you be of the party, Sir? We shall want a fourth hand.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Savage as the customed, I close with that proposal, and tho' I am not illegible quarrel. I shall illegible justice of it; and illegible
illegible ence.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
Sir, you're a gentleman of honour, and I shall be glad of being better known illegible ha illegible 'e illegible , Belcour, I had like to he illegible
illegible part of my illegible : there is the illegible it over faith; 'tis illegible the illegible can p illegible t you to death with a safe conscience, and when he has done that job for you, let it be a warning how you at
tempt the sister of illegible .

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: The sister?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Ay, the sister: illegible English, illegible all one; you illegible ley, that illegible by St. Patrick, illegible b illegible ¦cour, to illegible from her, when there are so many to be met in this town, who have dispos'd of th illegible ir' illegible to you hand illegible .

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Why I am thunderstruck! what is it you have done, and what is the shocking business in which I have en
gaged! If I understood him illegible young Dudley you've been attempting▪ y illegible u illegible to me of a profest wanton; the girl he speaks of has beauty enough indeed to inflame your desires, but she has honour, innocence and simplicity to awe the most licentious passion; if you have illegible that, Mr. Belcour, I renounce you, I abandon you, I forswear all fellow
ship or friendship with you for ever.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Have patience for a moment; we do indeed speak of the same person, but she is not innocent, she is not young Dudley's sister.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Astonishing! who told you this?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: The woman where she lodges; the person who put me on the pursuit and contriv'd our meetings.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: What woman? What person?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Fulmer her name is: I warrant you I did not pro
ceed without good grounds.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Fulmer, Fulmer? Who waits? a Servant enters send Mr. Stukely hither directly; I begin to see my way into this dark transaction: Mr. Belcour, Mr. Bel
cour, your are no match for the cunning and con
trivances of this intriguing town. Stukely enters prythee, Stukely, what is the name of the woman and her husband, who were stopt upon suspicion of selling stolen diamonds at our next-door neighbour's, the jeweller?

sp.speaker: STUKELY.
sp.p: Fulmer.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Can you procure me a sight of those diamonds?

sp.speaker: STUKELY.
sp.p: They are now in my hand; I was desir'd to show them to Mr. Stockwell.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Give 'em to me: what do I see? As I live, the very diamonds Miss Rusport sent hither, and which I in
trusted to you to return.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Yes, but I betray'd that trust, and gave 'em Mrs. Fulmer to present to Miss Dudley.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: With a view no doubt to bribe her to compliance.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I own it.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
For shame, for shame? and 'twas this woman's in
telligence you relied upon for Miss Dudley's character?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I thought she knew her; by Heaven, I wou'd have died sooner than have insulted a woman of virtue, or a man of honour.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I think you wou'd, but mark the danger of licentious courses; you are betray'd, robb'd, abus'd, and but for this providential discovery in a fair way of being sent out of the world with all your follies on your head— Dear Stukely, go to my neighbour, tell him I have an owner for the jewels, and beg him to carry the people under custody to the London Tavern, and wait for me there. Exit Stukely.
I fear the law does not provide a punishment to reach the villiany of these people; but how in the name of wonder cou'd you take any thing on the word of such an informer?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Because I had not liv'd long enough in your country to know how few informers words are to be taken: perswaded however as I was of Miss Dudley's guilt, I must own to you I was stagger'd with the appearance of such innocence, especially when I saw her admitted into Miss Rusport's company.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Good Heaven! did you meet her at, Miss Rusport's, and cou'd you doubt her being a woman of reputa
tion?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: By you perhaps such a mistake cou'd not have been made, but in a perfect stranger, I hope it is venial: I did not know what artifices young Dudley might have us'd to conceal her character; I did not know what disgrace attended the detection of it.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I see it was a trap laid for you, which you have narrowly escap'd; you address'd a woman of honour with all the loose incense of a profane admirer, and you have drawn upon you the resentment of a man of honour who thinks himself bound to protect her: Well, Sir, you must atone for this mistake.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: To the lady the most penitent submission I can make is justly due, but in the execution of an act of justice it never shall be said my soul was swayed by the least particle of fear: I have received a challenge from her brother; now tho' I wou'd give my fortune, almost my life itself, to purchase her happiness, yet I cannot abate her one scruple of my honour; I have been branded with the name of villain.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, you mistook her character and he mistook yours; error begets error.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Villain, Mr. Stockwell, is a harsh word.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: It is a harsh word, and should be unsaid.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR
sp.p: Come, come, it shall be unsaid.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Or else what follows? why the sword is drawn and to heal the wrongs you have done to the reputation of the sister, you make an honourable amends by murder
ing the brother.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Murdering!

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
'Tis thus religion writes and speaks the word; in the vocabulary of modern honour there is no such term—But come, I don't despair of satisfying the one without alarming the other; that done, I have a dis
covery to unfold that you will then I hope be fitted to receive.

div.head: SCENE I. The London Tavern.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: GEntlemen, well met! you understand each other's minds, and as I see you have brought nothing but your swords, you may set to without any further ceremony.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: You will not find us backward in any worthy cause; but before we proceed any further, I would ask this young gentleman, whether he has any explanation to require of Mr. Belcour.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
Of Mr. Belcour none; his actions speak for them
selves: but to you, sir, I would fain propose one question.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: How is it, Mr. Stockwell, that I meet a man of your character on this ground?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I will answer you directly, and my answer shall not displease you. I come hither in defence of the reputa
tion of Miss Dudley, to redress the injuries of an in
nocent young lady.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: By my soul the man knows he's to fight, only he mistakes which side he's to be of.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
You are about to draw your sword to refute a charge against your sister's honour; you would do well, if there were no better means within reach; but the proofs of her innocence are lodg'd in our bosoms, and
if we fall, you destroy the evidence that most effectu
ally can clear her fame.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: How's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: This gentleman could best explain it to you, but you have given him an undeserv'd name that seals his lips against you: I am not under the same inhibition, and if your anger can keep cool for a few minutes, I desire I may call in two witnesses, who will solve all difficulties at once. Here, waiter! bring those people in that are without.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Out upon it, what need is there for so much talking about the matter; can't you settle your differences first, and dispute about 'em afterwards?

div.stage: FULMER and Mrs. FULMER brought in.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Fulmer and his wife in custody?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, these are your honest landlord and land
lady, now in custody for defrauding this gentleman of certain diamonds intended to have been presented to your sister. Be so good, Mrs. Fulmer, to inform the company why you so grossly scandalized the reputation of an innocent lady, by persuading Mr. Belcour that Miss Dudley was not the sister, but the mistress, of this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FULMER.
sp.p: Sir, I don't know what right you have to question me, and I shall not answer till I see occasion.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Had you been as silent heretofore, Madam, it would have saved you some trouble; but we don't want your confession. This letter, which you wrote to Mr. Bel
cour, will explain your design; and these diamonds, which of right belong to Miss Rusport, will confirm your guilt: the law, Mrs. Fulmer, will make you speak, tho' I can't. Constable, take charge of your prisoners.

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p:
Hold a moment: Mr. Stockwell, you are a gentle
man that knows the world, and a member of parlia
ment; we shall not attempt to impose upon you; we know we are open to the law, and we know the ut
most it can do against us. Mr. Belcour has been ill used to be sure, and so has Miss Dudley; and, for my own part, I always condemn'd the plot as a very foolish plot, but it was a child of Mrs. Fulmer's brain, and she would not be put out of conceit with it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FULMER.
sp.p: You are a very foolish man, Mr. Fulmer, so prythee hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: FULMER.
sp.p:
Therefore, as I was saying, if you send her to Bride-well, it won't be amiss; and if you give her a little wholesome discipline, she may be the better for that too: but for me, Mr. Stockwell, who am a man of letters, I must beseech you, Sir, not to bring any dis
grace upon my profession.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
'Tis you, Mr. Fulmer, not I, that disgrace your profession, therefore begone, nor expect that I will betray the interests of mankind so far as to shew fa
vour to such incendiaries. Take 'em away; I blush to think such wretches should have the power to set two honest men at variance.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Mr. Belcour, we have mistaken each other; let us exchange forgiveness. I am convinced you intended no affront to my sister, and I ask your pardon for the expression I was betrayed into.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, Sir; the error began on my side, and was Miss Dudley here, I would be the first to atone.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Let us all adjourn to my house, and conclude the evening like friends: you will find a little entertain
ment ready for you; and, if I am not mistaken, Miss
Dudley and her father will make part of our company. Come, Major, do you consent?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Most readily, Mr. Stockwell; a quarrel well made up, is better than a victory hardly earned. Give me your hand, Belcour; o' my conscience you are too honest for the country you live in. And now, my dear lad, since peace is concluded on all sides, I have a discovery to make to you, which you must find out for yourself, for deuce take me if I rightly comprehend it, only that your aunt Rusport is in a conspiracy against you, and a vile rogue of a lawyer, whose name I forget, at the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: What conspiracy? Dear Major, recollect yourself.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: By my soul, I've no faculty at recollecting myself; but I've a paper somewhere about me, that will tell you more of the matter than I can. When I get to the merchant's, I will endeavour to find it.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Well, it must be in your own way; but I confess you hare thoroughly rous'd my curiosity.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: And are those wretches, Fulmer and his wife, in safe custody?

sp.speaker: STUKELY.
sp.p: They are in good hands, I accompanied them to the Tavern, where your son was to be, and then went in search of you. You may be sure Mr. Stockwell will enforce the law against them as far as it will go.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: What mischief might their cursed machinations have produced, but for this timely discovery!

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
Still I am terrified; I tremble with apprehension lest Mr. Belcour's impetuosity and Charles's spirit shou'd not wait for an explanation, but drive them both to extremes, before the mistake can be unra
vell'd.

sp.speaker: STUKELY.
sp.p:
Mr. Stockwell is with them, Madam, and you have nothing to fear; you cannot suppose he wou'd ask you hither for any other purpose, but to celebrate their re
conciliation and to receive Mr. Belcour's attonement.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p:
No, no, Louisa, Mr. Stockwell's honour and dis
cretion guard us against all danger or offence; he well knows we will endure no imputation on the honour of our family, and he certainly has invited us to receive satisfaction on that score in an amicable way.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Wou'd to Heaven they were return'd!

sp.speaker: STUKELY.
sp.p:
You may expect them every minute; and see Ma
dam, agreeable to your wish, they are here.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: CHARLES enters, and afterwards STOCKWELL and O'FLAHERTY.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
O Charles, O brother, how cou'd you serve me so how cou'd you tell me you was going to Lady Rus
port's and then set out with a design of fighting Mr. Belcour? But where is he; where is your antagonist?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Captain, I am proud to see you, an you Miss Dud
ley, do me particular honour: We have been adjust
ing, Sir, a very extraordinary and dangerous mistake, which I take for granted my friend Stukely has ex
plain'd to you.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p:
He has; I have too good an opinion of Mr. Bel
cour to believe he cou'd be guilty of a design'd affront to an innocent girl, and I am much too well acquainted with your character to suppose you cou'd abet him in such design; I have no doubt therefore all things will be set to rights in very few words when we have the pleasure of seeing Mr. Belcour.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: He has only stept into the compting-house and will wait upon you directly: You will not be over strict, Madam, in weighing Mr. Belcour's conduct to the minutest scruple; his manners, passions and opinions are not as yet affimilated to this climate; he comes amongst you a new character, an inhabitant of a new world and both hospitality as well as pity recommend him to our indulgence.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: BELCOUR enters, bows to Miss DUDLEY.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I am happy and asham'd to see you; no man in his senses wou'd offend you; I forfeited mine and err'd against the light of the sun, when I overlook'd your virtues; but your beauty was predominant and hid them from my sight; I now perceive I was the dupe of a most improbable report, and humbly entreat your pardon.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Think no more of it; 'twas a mistake.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
My life has been compos'd of little else; 'twas found
ed in mystery and has continued in error: I was once given to hope, Mr. Stockwell, that you was to have deliver'd me from these difficulties, but either I do not deserve your confidence, or I was deceiv'd in my ex
pectations.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: When this lady has confirm'd your pardon, I shall hold you deserving of my confidence.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: That was granted the moment it was ask'd.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
To prove my title to his confidence honour me so far with your's as to allow me a few minutes conver
sation in private with you.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: By all means, Louisa; come, Mr. Stockwell, let us go into another room.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
And now, major O'Flaherty, I claim your promise of a sight of the paper, that is to unravel this conspi
racy of my aunt Rusport's: I think I have waited with great patience.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: I have been endeavouring to call to mind what it was I overheard; I've got the paper and will give you the best account I can of the whole transaction.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Miss Dudley, I have solicited this audience to repeat to you my penitence and confusion: How shall I atone? What reparation can I make to you and vir
tue?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: To me there's nothing due, nor any thing demanded of you but your more favourable opinion for the future, if you should chance to think of me: Upon the part of virtue I'm not empower'd to speak, but if hereafter, as you range thro' life, you shou'd surprize her in the person of some wretched female, poor as myself and not so well protected, enforce not your advantage, compleat not your licentious triumph, but raise her, rescue her from shame and sorrow, and reconcile her to herself again.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I will, I will; by bearing your idea ever present in my thoughts, virtue shall keep an advocate within me; but tell me, loveliest, when you pardon the offence, can you, all pe illegible fect as you are, approve of the offender? As I now cease to view you in that false light I lately did, can you, and in the fulness of your bounty will you, cease also to reflect upon the libertine addresses I have paid you, and look upon me as your reform'd, your rational admirer?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Are sudden reformations apt to last; and how can I be sure the first fair face you meet will not ensnare affections so unsteady, and that I shall not lose you lightly as I gain'd you?

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Because tho' you conquer'd me by surprize, I have no inclination to rebel; because since the first moment that I saw you, every instant has improv'd you in my eyes, because by principle as well as passion I am un
alterably yours, in short there are ten thousand causes for my love to you, would to Heaven I could plant one in your soft bosom that might move you to return it!

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Belcour.—

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
I know I am not worthy your regard; I know I'm tainted with a thousand faults, sick of a thousand fol
lies, but there's a healing virtue in your eyes that makes recovery certain; I cannot be a villain in your arms.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: That you can never be; whomever you shall honour with your choice, my life upon't that woman will be happy; it is not from suspicion that I hesitate, it is from honour; tis the severity of my condition, it is the world that never will interpret fairly in our case.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Oh, what am I, and who in this wide would con
cerns himself for such a nameless, such a friendless th illegible ▪ as I am? I set, Miss Dudley, illegible not yet illegible your pardon.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Nay, that you are in full possession of.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Oh, seal it with your hand then, loveliest of women, confirm it with your heart; make me honourably happy, and crown your penitent not with your pardon only, but your love.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: My love!—

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
By Heav'n my soul is conquer'd with your virtues more than my eyes are ravish'd with your beauty Oh, may this fo illegible , this sensit illegible ve alarm be happy, be a illegible ∣cious! Doubt not, deliberate not, delay illegible . If hap
piness be the end of life, why do we sup illegible a moment▪

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: O'FLAHERTY enters, and afterwards DUDLEY and CHARLES with STOCKWELL.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Joy, joy, joy! sing, dance, leap, laugh for joy! Ha' done making love and fall down on your knees to every saint in the illegible , for they're all on your side and honest St. Patrick at the head of them.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: O Louisa, such an event by the illegible chan illegible e in life we have discover'd a will of illegible grandfa illegible er's made in his last illness, by which he out of my Aunt Rusport with a small annuity, and leaves me heir to his whole estate, with a fortune of fifteen thousand pounds to yourself.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
What is it you tell me? O Sir, instruct me to sup
port this unexpected turn of fortune.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: Name not fortune; 'tis he work of providence, 'tis the justice of Heaven that wou'd not suffer innocence to be oppress'd, nor your base aunt to prosper in her cruelty and cunning.

div.stage: A servant whispers Belcour, and he goes out.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, Capt. Dudley, but you must not overlook St. Patrick neither, for by my soul if he had not put it into my head to slip behind the screen when your righteous aunt and the lawyer were plotting together, I don't see how you wou'd ever have come at the paper there, that Master Stockwell is reading.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: True my good friend, you are the father of this discovery, but how did you contrive to get this will from the lawyer?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: By force, my dear, the only way of getting any thing from a lawyer's clutches.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Well, Major, when he brings his action of assault and battery against you, the least Dudley can do is to defend you with the weapons you have put into his hands.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
That I am bound to do, and after the happiness I shall have in sheltering a father's age from the vicissi
tudes of life, my next delight will be in offering you an asylum in the bosom of your country.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: And upon my soul, my dear, 'tis high time I was there, for 'tis now thirty long years since I sat foot in my native country, and by the power of St. Patrick I swear I think it's worth all the rest of the world put together.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p:
Ay, Major, much about that time have I been heat
ing the round of service, and 'twere well for us both to
give over; we have stood many a tough gale and abun
dance of hard blows, but Charles shall lay us up in a little private, but safe, harbour, where we'll rest from our labours, and peacefully wind up the remainder of our days.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Agreed, and you may take it as a proof of my esteem, young man, that Major O'Flaherty accepts a favour at your Bands, for by Heaven I'd sooner starve, than say I thank you to the man I despise: But I believe you are an honest lad, and I'm glad you've trounc'd the old cat, for on my conscience I believe I must otherwise have married her myself to have let you in for a share of her fortune.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Hey day, what's become of Belcour?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: One of your servants call'd him out just now and seemingly on some earnest occasion.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
I hope, Miss Dudley, he has aton'd to you as a gen
tleman ought.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: Mr. Belcour, Sir, will always do what a gentleman ought, and in my case I fear only you will think he has done too much.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: What has he done; and what can be too much? Pray Heaven, it may be as I wish!

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: Let us hear it, child.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: With confusion for my own unworthiness, I confess to you he has offer'd me—

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Himself.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Then I am happy; all my doubts, my cares are over, and I may own him for my son.——Why these are joyful tidings: come, my good friend, assist me in disposing your lovely daughter to accept this returning prodigal; he is no unprincipled, no harden'd libertine; his love for you and virtue is the same.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: 'Twere vile ingratitude in me to doubt his merit— What says my child?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Begging your pardon now, 'tis a frivolous sort of a question, that of yours; for you may see plainly enough by the young lady's looks, that she says a great deal, though she speaks never a word.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
Well, sister, I believe the Major has fairly inter
preted the state of your heart.

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: I own it; and what must that heart be, which love, honour and beneficence like Mr. Belcour's can make no impression on?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I thank you: What happiness has this hour brought to pass!

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Why don't we all sit down to supper then and make a night on't.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Hold, here comes Belcour.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p:
Mr. Dudley, here is a fair refugee, who properly comes under your protection; she is equipt for Scot
land,
but your good fortune, which I have related to her, seems inclin'd to save you both the journey— Nay, Madam, never go back; you are amongst friends.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Charlotte!

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: The same; that fond officious girl, that haunts you every where; that persecuting spirit—

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Say rather, that protecting angel; such you have been to me.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: O Charles, you have an honest, but proud heart.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Nay, chide me not, dear Charlotte.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Seal up her lips then; she is an adorable girl; her arms are open to you; and love and happiness are ready to receive you.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Thus then I claim my dear, my destin'd wife.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Heyday! mighty fine! wife truly! mighty well! kissing, embracing—did ever any thing equal this? Why you shameless hussey!—But I won't condescend to waste a word upon you.—You, Sir, you, Mr. Stockwell, you fine, sanctified, fair-dealing man of conscience, is this the principle you trade upon? Is this your neighbourly system, to keep a house of recep
tion for run-away daughters, and young beggarly fortune-hunters?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Be advis'd now, and don't put yourself in such a passion; we were all very happy till you came.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Stand away, Sir; hav'nt I a reason to be in a pas
sion?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Indeed, honey, and you have, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Come, Madam, I have found out your haunts; dis
pose yourself to return home with me: young man, let me never see you within my doors again: Mr. Stock
well, I shall report your behaviour, depend on it.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Hold, Madam, I cannot consent to lose Miss Rus
port's company this evening, and I am persuaded you won't insist upon it; 'tis an unmotherly action to in
terrupt your daughter's happiness in this manner, be
lieve me it is.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Her happiness truly; upon my word! and I suppose it's an unmotherly action to interrupt her ruin; for what but ruin must it be to marry a beggar? I think my sister had a proof of that, Sir, when she made choice of you.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: Don't be too lavish of your spirits, Lady Rusport.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p:
By my soul you'll have occasion for a sip of the cor
dial Elixir by and bye.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: It don't appear to me, Madam, that Mr. Dudley can be call'd a beggar.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: But it appears to me, Mr. Stockwell; I am apt to think a pair of colours cannot furnish settlement quite sufficient for the heiress of Sir Stephen Rusport.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: But a good estate in aid of a commission may do something.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: A good estate, truly! where shou'd he get a good estate pray?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Why suppose now a worthy old gentleman on his death-bed should have taken it in mind to leave him one—

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Hah! what's that you say?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: O ho! you begin to smell a plot, do you?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Suppose there should be a paper in the world that runs thus—"I do hereby give and bequeath all my estates, real and personal, to Charles Dudley, son of my late daughter Louisa, &c. &c. &c."

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Why I am thunder-struck! by what contrivance, what villany did you get possession of that paper?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: There was no villany, Madam, in getting possession of it; the crime was in concealing it, none in bringing it to light.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Oh, that cursed lawyer, Varland!

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: You may say that, faith, he is a cursed lawyer, and a cursed piece of work I had to get the paper from him; your ladyship now was to have paid him five thousand pounds for it, I forc'd him to give it me of his own accord for nothing at all, at all.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Is it you that have done this? Am I foil'd by your blundering contrivances, after all?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: 'Twas a blunder, faith, but as natural a one as if I'd made it o' purpose.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Come, let us not oppress the fallen; do right even now, and you shall have no cause to complain.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p:
Am I become an object of your pity then? Insuffer
able! confusion light amongst you! marry and be wretched: let me never see you more.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: She is outrageous; I suffer for her, and blush to see her thus exposed.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p:
Come, Charlotte, don't let this angry woman dis
turb our happiness: we will save her in spite of her
self; your father's memory shall not be stained by the discredit of his second choice.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: I trust implicitly to your discretion, and am in all things yours.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Now, lovely but obdurate, does not this example soften?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p:
What can you ask for more? Accept my hand, ac
cept my willing heart.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: O bliss inutterable! brother, father, friend, and you the author of this general joy—

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Blessing of St. Patrick upon us all! 'tis a night of wonderful and surprizing ups and downs: I wish we were all fairly set down to supper, and there was an end on't.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
Hold for a moment! I have yet one word to inter
pose—Intitled by my friendship to a voice in your dis
posal, I have approv'd your match; there yet remains a father's consent to be obtain'd.

sp.speaker: BELCOOUR.
sp.p: Have I a father?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
You have a father: did not I tell you I had a dis
covery to make? Compose yourself: you have a father, who observes, who knows, who loves you.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Keep me no longer in suspence; my heart is soften'd for the affecting discovery, and nature fits me to receive his blessing.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I am your father.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: My father? Do I live?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I am your father.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: It is too much; my happiness o'erpowers me; to gain a friend and find a father is too much; I blush to think how little I deserve you.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: See, children, how many new relations spring from this night's unforeseen events, to endear us to each other.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: O my conscience, I think we shall be all related by and bye.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
How happily has this evening concluded, and yet how threatning was its approach! let us repair to the supper room, where I will unfold to you every circum
stance of my mysterious story. Yes, Belcour, I have
watch'd you with a patient, but enquiring eye, and I have discover'd thro' the veil of some irregularities, a heart beaming with benevolence, an animated nature, fallible indeed, but not incorrigible; and your election of this excellent young lady makes me glory in acknow
ledging you to be my son.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I thank you, and in my turn glory in the father I have gained: sensibly imprest with gratitude for such extraordinary dispensations, I beseech you, amiable Louisa, for the time to come, whenever you perceive me deviating into error or offence, bring only to my mind the Providence of this night, and I will turn to reason and obey.
